text: Discord has no history restriction, and its pretty good otherwise

text:
chat, opinion piece & peer reviewed - Off the top of my head I can think of 3 written forms, chat, opinion piece & peer reviewed. I assume the output of the group would be in written form and then there is also the podcast. ... also there is group collaboration, but collaboration is a twist on how the output is created, with group refinements to the format of the written output. Maybe it is worth having both opinion pieces & peer reviewed sections in the newsletter.

Re: zulipchat - I have not used this, it looks a bit like google wave - <@U6KQ2S410> - Am guessing you have used zulipchat, and slack. What would you say is the main advantage of zulipchat over slack?

text: May I suggest <https://spectrum.chat> as an alternative? I must say I find zulipchat not very appealing visually…

text: Old fashioned web-based bulletin boards like phpbb work(ed) quite will for topical conversations.

elements.text: Old fashioned web-based bulletin boards like phpbb work(ed) quite will for topical conversations.
More visual programming stuff? Cool! :-)

text: I haven't seen Zulip before. To me, it looks to offer very similar features and purpose to Slack, but with a handful of our biggest pains alleviated, and a lot of thoughtful improvements. I agree with Martin that it's a bit ugly, and that matters to me (and surely others here), but of all the options I've seen so far this looks the most promising — and I suspect the look & feel will improve with time, since that's easier to change than the underlying communication paradigm. Can anyone with Zulip experience share any shortcomings they've found compared to Slack?

elements.text: I haven't seen Zulip before. To me, it looks to offer very similar features and purpose to Slack, but with a handful of our biggest pains alleviated, and a lot of thoughtful improvements. I agree with Martin that it's a bit ugly, and that matters to me (and surely others here), but of all the options I've seen so far this looks the most promising — and I suspect the look & feel will improve with time, since that's easier to change than the underlying communication paradigm. Can anyone with Zulip experience share any shortcomings they've found compared to Slack?

text: Also, Zulip looks like it has _everything_ that I've seen people ask for. Full history search, search engine indexing, rich permalinks, free, mobile apps, Linux, better threading, Slack import, unlimited history. I like that they specifically say accessibility is a feature.

elements.text: Also, Zulip looks like it has
everything

that I've seen people ask for. Full history search, search engine indexing, rich permalinks, free, mobile apps, Linux, better threading, Slack import, unlimited history. I like that they specifically say accessibility is a feature.

attachments.title: Zulip Features
attachments.text: First class threading on top of everything you could want from real-time chat.

elements.text: https://zulipchat.com/features/

attachments.title: Modern chat for open source
attachments.text: No message limits, rich moderation features, markdown support, and a conversation model that scales to thousands of users.
attachments.fallback: Zulip: Modern chat for open source

elements.text: https://zulipchat.com/for/open-source/

text: 20 hours per month… Crossing my fingers against burnout and competition with other projects! Are you planning to start a Patreon as Steve said you might?

text: <@UC2A2ARPT> thank you for taking on the stewardship of this community. Having this community humming along is super valuable and I (and I assume everyone else here) really appreciate the time and effort you have decided to put into it.

text:
Some of us tried spectrum a while ago Here's the link to the trial chatroom if anyone wants to try: <https://spectrum.chat/programmablesystems?tab=posts>

It seems like a chat/forum hybrid. The first post gives you an easier way to write longform but it makes it easy to reply as a chat message (enter will submit the message).

elements.text: Some of us tried spectrum a while ago Here's the link to the trial chatroom if anyone wants to try:
It seems like a chat/forum hybrid. The first post gives you an easier way to write longform but it makes it easy to reply as a chat message (enter will submit the message).

text:
Between zulip and spectrum I liked the spectrum UI a lot more. I can follow the different chat channels and the messages inside them. I'm always a bit lost in zulip. BTW I think spectrum has joined github (and so microsoft).

I believe gtoolkit from <@UE1JQM9HQ> uses spectrum:  <https://spectrum.chat/gtoolkit?tab=posts>

text:
Zulip has a kind of "indie" feel and level of support, but it is _much_ better at threading and persistence.

Agree with the sentiment of caution about uprooting the discussion from a "settled" colony

text:
So VS Code is going to be more than a text editor... if I were going to make a custom editor, living in VS Code would be attractive. Looks like one must write it in TS/JS.

"We continued to work on the custom editor proposal this iteration. (<https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/77131>) As a reminder, custom editors are webview-based views that can be used in place of VS Code's normal text editor for specific file types. As of VS Code 1.41, Custom editors can now integrate with VS Code's Undo/Redo and Save functionality, which enables many interesting use cases including using them as visual and WYSIWYG editors.

You can find the current API proposal in `vscode.proposed.d.ts` (<https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/vscode.proposed.d.ts>) and we have also put together some very simple extension samples that demonstrate using custom editors for text and for binary files. (<https://github.com/mjbvz/vscode-experimental-webview-editor-extension>)

If you are interested in custom editors, please share your feedback on the current proposal and let us know if you would be able to implement it."

elements.text:

"We continued to work on the custom editor proposal this iteration. (

) As a reminder, custom editors are webview-based views that can be used in place of VS Code's normal text editor for specific file types. As of VS Code 1.41, Custom editors can now integrate with VS Code's Undo/Redo and Save functionality, which enables many interesting use cases including using them as visual and WYSIWYG editors.

You can find the current API proposal in
vscode.proposed.d.ts
) and we have also put together some very simple extension samples that demonstrate using custom editors for text and for binary files. (

)

If you are interested in custom editors, please share your feedback on the current proposal and let us know if you would be able to implement it."

text:
Spectrum's infinite scrolling implementation is pretty janky. Eg: when you open a thread and then go back to the channel, it loses your scroll position — you're always dumped back at the top.

How does spectrum do for permalinks?

elements.text:
Spectrum's infinite scrolling implementation is pretty janky. Eg: when you open a thread and then go back to the channel, it loses your scroll position — you're always dumped back at the top.

How does spectrum do for permalinks?

text: <@UFEQUBNNT> Yeah, 20 hours is a lot, but I'm hoping that'll improve once I settle on a good process. As for Patreon, we'll see. It'd be nice if the podcast were able to bring in enough money to pay for itself (hosting, transcript, and maybe a little for my effort). <http://Repl.it|Repl.it> have been a big help so far. But I'm sensitive to subscription fatigue being a thing, so there might be better options than Patreon — for instance, a second sponsor. I welcome any thoughts or suggestions, here or in DMs.

elements.text: Yeah, 20 hours is a lot, but I'm hoping that'll improve once I settle on a good process. As for Patreon, we'll see. It'd be nice if the podcast were able to bring in enough money to pay for itself (hosting, transcript, and maybe a little for my effort). Repl.it have been a big help so far. But I'm sensitive to subscription fatigue being a thing, so there might be better options than Patreon — for instance, a second sponsor. I welcome any thoughts or suggestions, here or in DMs.
